oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lee Sadler's Civil War Veteran Questionaire
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Veterans; Slaveholders; Agriculture - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Questionnaire response of Confederate soldier Lee Sadler, completed in 1922 when he was 79. He states the value of his property and his family's property before, during, and after the war and whether they owned slaves; he comments on the social aspects of his community, his level of education, and the circumstances of his enlistment in the Civil War. He also explains his war-time service and activities since the war ended.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sadler, Lee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1914 Tennessee State Archivist Gus Dyer developed a questionnaire and contacted all known Tennessee Civil War Veterans in an effort to record their experiences before, during, and after the war. In 1920 the project was continued by then State Libriarian and Archivist John Trotwood Moore and the Tennessee Historical Commission. By conclusion of the program in 1922, 1,650 completed forms had been returned and were made available for research.
